text: Patient: So then I’m eating, uh- Family Member: My diet. Doctor: You’re just eating protein. Patient: Seven days a week eating eggs. Doctor: Well, there’s other foods other than eggs. But carbs for you are like, forget it. Forget it. They’re disastrous. Family Member: Cancer feeds on it. Family Member: Right? Am I wrong there? Doctor: Well, it isn’t. You know what it is? It creates an unhealthy environment for you. And for all the other stuff I may potentially have to do for you, to you, however we want to say that, I need you functioning and that diabetes can’t be in my way. Gosh darn it. Doctor: Yeah. Plus unregulated, and I mean this up and down, your body just doesn’t like it. So the steady state might be alright at a hemoglobin A one C of seven two but your every day, what you get is tired. You crash. You go back up. You’re good. You crash. You’re tired. You come back up. That’s not, boom, okay. Patient: So then like I again explained to Dr. W___ about my, about my fatigue. Doctor: Um hum. Yes. Patient: Is my lack of uninterrupted sleep. I just don’t get it.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - um that the side effects from the hormone therapies were getting a little bit too much for you. Patient: Yes. Doctor: And your preference, which I agreed with at the time, was to stop the Lupron you get. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And given that your PSA level is very low, it was an investment point level, that you basically stop that, allow the testosterone to recover if you did good by itself, and then to monitor the PSA to see where that was at. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So on the one hand, it does move over time, if the testosterone continues to increase, which it probably will, may feed the cancer. But on the other hand, in the meantime, your quality of life should be better than it would have been with a testosterone let’s say less than twenty. Patient: Okay. That’s’ Doctor: So it’s kind of the choice that we made, and this is sort of the natural expectation of what we were expecting to see. Patient: You would recommend having it done Doc? Doctor: No. There’s no evidence that people like you that people like you in controlling cancer. Patient: You know I was reading an article a while back that I like about it’s going to become common for folks to live into their hundreds.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: The computer makes the decision as to whether you get the extra drug or not. Patient: Okay. And so that’s why I put this appointment on the books. So let’s get the hormones started. You know you will say, “I want it; I don’t want it; I do want it.” In other words I’m not trying to put, you know but we have to have and then your opinion back. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So we weren’t making any decisions. So I’m delighted today that you feel better, that you can’t complain of anything. Patient: Right. Doctor: Your creatinine is down at one. And then if you’re still interested, then we would go for it. If you say, “I’m not interested”, if you’re not interested then you have to think about when do we start you know the chemotherapy. text: Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, and I was like just and then she was on the phone, I was like did she mean now or did she mean before? Family Member: No, because he was in pain; he was in pain. Doctor: Where is your worst pain do you think? Patient: Right here. Doctor: Still. Well, you’ve got some new spots on the bone scan. That’s one of them and upper spine is the other, you know kind of like of like by the neck area. So I don’t think this Xtandi is holding you as much as we’d like. Family Member: But it is holding him, right? Doctor: Some parts of it but I think we have to think about adding something else to the mix here or stopping it. And I just want to double-check. You’re still taking Xtandi? Okay, and are you alternating like number of pills per day or are you just - Patient: Four a day. Doctor: Okay, so you know you don’t have much room to go from that because that’s the max dose. But when you break through from the bone scan it tells me it’s really not working. The stuff that’s being not - you know it’s not in your liver or anything else. Like it’s just still in the bone and you’ve got pain actually suggests we could try a different treatment called Xofigo. And I mentioned this like a while back. This is that radium stuff that Marie Curie discovered many years ago. I don’t know if you guys remember that from elementary school. But it basically kills, you know, cancer in the bones. Well in her case she died because she was carrying too much of it in her pocket. But in patients, it’s now in legit treatment for men with prostate cancer that has gone to bone. Family Member: Does that look - something you inject, like a pill or capsule or something? Doctor: No, it’s actually, they put an I.V. in you and it comes in a – it’s a liquid. It’s like liquid radiation, and they draw it up and then they just inject it in you. It’s like you know, it’s like in, in over a minute, and it’s once a month for six months. The person that is the expert is the radiation oncology doctor, and that person knows how to regulate obviously radiation. This is a form of radiation. Family Member: Is that what they did to him before when he went down there? They -

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
